The shortest but still worth "expansion" to the original Half-Life.

Sadly the game, what I could just call an add-on, adds nothing particularly new apart from a new mix-up to the health and armor mechanic, is the shortest and least engaging out of the 3 campaigns for the original Half-Life on PC. From scientist turned into a worthy warrior and a corporal that can hold his ground all of his own we go to a security guard that sadly just offers perspective on important events, but doesn't really have much charm or "specialty" like Freeman or Shephard had during their adventures.

[h1]Quick Summary[/h1]
Half-Life: Blue Shift had the right idea, but executed it poorly. If you're in it for nostalgia or just a completionist (like me) looking to see it all, then pick up this game and give it a run. Otherwise, Half-Life and Half-Life: Opposing Force are far better installments. Blue Shift is both short and bland. There's very little enemy diversity, weaponry feels scarce, and the progression is fairly linear. I'd say this is more of a speed running game than it is an experience.

[h1]My Full Review[/h1]
Half-Life: Blue Shift is dated in the same ways the base game and previous expansion is. This is to be expected of course! Overall, the gameplay is still Half-Life, but I feel like that's all it is... just "more Half-Life". This game is an easy pass to those less enthusiastic about the universe. You'll find the better experiences in Half-Life and Half-Life: Opposing Force.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Overall, the game feels so linear and basic that it'd be overall forgettable if it wasn't attached to the Half-Life franchise. Not only is the weaponry more limited than even the base game, but even the enemies feel repetitive. Most of the environments in this game feel uninspired and in some ways underdeveloped than the previous installments. Other than a section or two, the game's progression is extremely predictable and unsatisfying.

Speaking of progression, it barely feels like there's any real progression happening. You spend most of your time running through various corridors or enclosed outdoor areas shooting a bunch of marines and head crabs. Point A to Point B with killing in between. If that's what you're looking for, you'll find just that in this game.

[h1]Story / Plot[/h1]
This expansion takes place in the perspective of Barney Calhoun right before the incident infamously started by Gordon Freeman. Alike the other Half-Life installments, you spend the game finding your way out of the Black Mesa facility.

That's about it. While we get to play from a new perspective, there really isn't any new information provided to us as far as the story is concerned. This was always the biggest letdown for me, because a new perspective often insinuates new information to some capacity. This game severely lacks in this department compared to its predecessors.

[h1]Graphics / Audio[/h1]
If you've played the previous Half-Life installments (which I highly recommend before attempting this installment), then you should expect all of the same. The graphics are definitely dated, but they're still very thematic to the universe and hold a visual mood that a lot of games don't come close to. No different than the first game, the audio is the weakest point here. The various sounds and voice lines are definitely showing age, but they were certainly fantastic for their time.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
This game is an easy pass, however it's not a terrible pickup for the major enthusiasts and completionists. Overall, you'll find better gameplay in the previous two installments.

[h1]Please Rate This Review[/h1]
I spend a lot of time breaking down game design and development from a critical consumer's perspective. If you've read all the way through, please give it a rating. The feedback helps!

Blue Shift es otra expansión de Half-Life. Jugás como Barney Calhoun, un guardia de seguridad de Black Mesa. Al principio, podés ver muchas ubicaciones de Black Mesa, algunas ya vistas en los juegos anteriores, y otras nuevas. Muy entretenido. A pesar de que dure solo la mitad de la de HL:OF, es muy disfrutable (me entretuve más con este juego que el HL:OF!). Abajo escribí un resumen del juego:

-SPOILER ALERT-


Más tarde, cuando el desastre ocurre, Barney lucha contra algunos monstruos de Xen y los HECU (No hay Black Ops en todo el juego). Los mismos que en el juego original, sin ninguna incorporación de armas (hay menos armas en este que en HL1). Después te encontrás con un científico que te dirige a un lugar antiguo de Black Mesa, con las mismas funciones que el Lambda Core. Te teletransportan a Xen para activar una máquina y te hacen volver y te envían aún más abajo para que hagas algo con un líquido. Una vez terminado todo eso, vos y un grupo de 3 científicos (incluyendo al científico que mencioné anteriormente) escapan formando un portal (escapás luchando al final con varios HECU) y sos el último en ser teletransportado. Algo sale mal y sos teletransportado a varias localizaciones (entre ellas, un lugar donde podes ver soldados llevándose a Freeman al compactador), pero finalmente volvés con ellos. Se van en una camioneta.
El juego se merece un 9/10

Seconde extension de Half-Life premier du nom, Blue Shift se trimballe la lourde réputation d'être la pire extension de la série et effectivement il en démérite.
Déjà, que ce soit au niveau des armes, des ennemis ou des décors : rien de nouveau, on refait ce que l'on a déjà fait. Par contre, en plus de ne rien apporter par rapport à ses prédécesseurs, il a même le mérite de régresser en proposant un level-design tout simplement raté ainsi qu'une pléthore de bogues qui n'apparaissaient pourtant pas auparavant.
J'ai par exemple dû passer le jeu en godmode (truc que de mémoire je n'avais pas fait depuis 2007-2008) car il y a un passage dans lequel je me suis retrouvé sans vie ni munitions face à des ennemis m'attaquant à distance dans des couloirs : si t'as pas prévu le coup et que t'as pas fait en sorte conserver le plus de munitions possibles alors c'est mort et t'as plus qu'à recommencer le jeu ou à le passer en godmode (en plus le checkpoint se trouve dans la même séquence).
En plus de ça, l'IA des PNJ est toujours aussi ratée et le seul scientifique qui doit te suivre durant l'extension est tellement teubé qu'il arrive à trouver le moyen de faire l'aller-retour entre le départ et l'objectif sans aucune raison.
Mise à part ça, il y a toujours de la plateforme (beurk), certains PNJ continuent de nous parler même une fois mort ou s'arrêtent en plein milieu de leur phrase, et on a toujours l'impression de contrôler un personnage avec du savon sous les chaussures.
C'est très oubliable et ce serait même plutôt à oublier tant ça ne fait pas honneur à la franchise.
Heureusement, ça ne dure environ que deux heures.
